that's fucktarded
so as a non-member of the CSS WG, there is no way to report a comment and be sure it won't get lost?
No comment

dude is going to find something to shout about regardless

othermaciej: speaking of trying to find something constructive to say, I have the same feeling about the chairs decision on meta generator
s/meta generator/*/
MikeSmith: do you think we should have agreed to reopen it based on the info provided?
for now I'll just say I feel zero motivation to actually ever again spend any time contributing to any more change proposals
othermaciej: yeah, I do
MikeSmith: or made a different decision in the first place?
that too
the thing we pretty clearly asked for, both in the original decision, and in response to the first reopen attempt, was specifics and evidence
I don't feel like it is that hard to find a few scraps of specific data
I just don't want to do the monkey dance, man
well, the bar for reopening an issue has to be higher than the bar for opening it in the first place
wodners if you are really supposed to get wyciwyg URLs in firefox history UI when you document.open/document.write/document.close
or nothing will even be settled
I think the information in that CP makes it quite clear what's wrong with the exception
*wonders
jgraham, in general, I wouldn't think so
hsivonen, ^
othermaciej, are you suggesting anything will ever be settled now?

I will add that I myself am not even sure the exception is a good idea, but the HTML WG process is optimized for procedural fairness, not for producing the outcome that is most technically optimal in the opinion of the chairs
(iirc, per spec, doing document.write on an existing document shouldn't create a new history position at all)]
(need to write some tests for that one day)
othermaciej: it's certainly become optimized that way in practice
I would much prefer to see a way to declare alt as intentionally unavailable due to wysiwygosity that is scoped instead of global to the document, but no one proposed such a thing
really on all these reopen requests, whichever way the chairs decide it will make a significant group of people mad
people who lost one time will be super annoyed to do extra work and still lose
people who won the last time will be super annoyed to have that jerked out from under them
actually I meant it seems in practice to have become optimized for procedural stuff rather for evaluation of what's technically optimal. Period.
othermaciej: there is very likely now going to be a formal objection on that issue
othermaciej: There was never a CP proposing scoped noalt?
so I guess it's eventually going to end up going to the Director
webben: I don't believe so
would it help if someone produced one now?
that's one problem with the CP process, it tends to polarize people to the extremes
It certainly seems like it would have more consensus than page-wide exemptions

webben: if it included new info that was sufficient to reopen the issue (e.g. argue that it meets all the use cases of generator but with less harm, with at least some specific piece of data to point to), then it would probably make a difference
I don't know anybody who has ever actually expressed strong support for the meta generator exception
MikeSmith: as with past FOs, I think I can live with that given the record (initial survey input, decision, request for particular kinds of additional info to reopen, refusal to provide such)
it's not refusal to provide such
director may overrule, but that is his prerrogative
it's disagreement about the need to provide it
I regret at this point ever actually implementing the meta generator exception in the validator code
and I'm not seriously considering to change the way it's implemented so that it's not on by default, and users have to opt in to it
because it's really a very bad idea for validation
a misfeature
s/not/now/?
yeah, now
trying to find the original ISSUE-31 questionnaire
do you know if there is a way to look at all questionnaires for a given WG?
yeah, lemme find it
there were three of them, but I can only find the two that are not relevant to generator
aha, http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-31-80-validation-objection-poll/results
othermaciej: https://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/closed
Hixie and hsivonen argued in favor of generator in the survey
Leif and Laura against
this covers both survey comments and CPs
yeah, I would like to hear more from Henri about it
to me the use case seems valid but I wish someone had proposed a cleaner mechanism to address it
global per-doc switches do not strike me as elegant or wise
yup
but the only options that were placed on the table were "don't meet this use case" or "use this somewhat squirrely solution for the use case"
I think it likely that a well-written proposal for a scoped mechanism to meet the use case (such as noalt) would have beaten both those options
jgraham: yes, you are really supposed to get wyciwyg URLs in Firefox.
jgraham: I don't like it, because WebKit get away with non-support for history navigation to document.open()ed and .written content
hsivonen: Doesn't the spec follow webkit?
(on this point :)
Also, I think Opera wants to follow WebKit on this point because in general getting an extra history position for document.write seems like it will create badness from the user point of view
On the basis that the typical use will be something like document.write into an about:blank iframe
Oh, I have now read the spec more closely and I am wrong about the document.open thing
But I still think it makes sense to folloow webkit
hsivonen: I filed https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=17093
jgraham: my vague recollection is that the spec is mostly WebKit-ish here
except of course the bug you just filed, apparently

othermaciej: how about allowing conformance checkers to provide a switch to suppress no alt for name=generator pages? that would provide the functionality for those who require it without it being silent
Stevef: interesting idea, I guess it would be sort of like the now-gone "private communications" exception
othermaciej: i discussed this with mike smith with his conformance checker implementor hat on and he said it sounded OK

I have no problem with it, but if anyone wanted to push it into the HTML WG's HTML5 spec at this point, it would require a Change Proposal with some reasonable level of new information indicating why it's better
othermaciej: making it an opt in provides the point of letting people know that using it only suppresses errors does not make the page conforming
othermaciej: right I am unsure about my desire to write another change proposal, just trying to avoid FO if possible
"Are there other cases in HTML where an attribute value contains more than one URI?"
head profile=""!
good of you to do so; unfortunately I have to go to bed so I can't provide more ideas
othermaciej:np
oh. Stevef left

Stevef: In case you continue to read the logs: The whole point of the generator thing is to make it so that *by default* validators are silent about missing alt in generated HTML so that generator developers don't feel a need to add bogus alt to silence validators.
Stevef: So if there was a switch, it would have to default to name=generator content being silent about missing alt and flipping the switch would turn on missing alt reporting.
Stevef: see http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20120518#l-384
hsivonen: I don't get the logic that it must be silent by default
Stevef: not getting the logic is the crux of the disagreement, I think
hsivonen:isn't an informed choice better?
Stevef: the whole generator thing is based on the observation that people who write HTML generators want to make the generated output get a clean report from a validator
Stevef: so if the validator complains *by default*, they'll change the generator's output to make it not complain
Stevef: the easiest adjustment being outputting bogus alt
(if you take a way the option of emitting <meta name=generator> and having that silence validators *by default*)
Stevef: emitting <meta name=generator> is an informed choice on the part of the person writing the HTML generator
Stevef: flipping a flag in the validator is a choice by the person invoking the validator
hsivonen: the use of genertaor does not bear that out
Stevef: not legacy use, sure
Stevef: anyway, the point is making it so that an HTML generator writer has no incentive to emit bogus alt in order to make it seem that the generator can generate "valid HTML"
many CMS's use name=generator by default any downstream user has to a know about its presence and its effect
hsivonen: i understand the arguement never seen any data to back it up
Stevef: I've not aware of quantitative data, but I've seen enough anectodal evidence to believe it. Of course, I haven't recorded all the anecdotes when I've seen them.
It's generally hard to substantiate anecdotal experience of having seen stuff after the fact.
It would probably be possible to come up with quantitative data by analysing various HTML4 generators and seeing if they generate bogus alts
(and make the assumption that the obvious explanation that everyone who has ever written a generator knows to be true explains the bogus alts)
hsivonen: i looked at a range of wysywig tools some do some don't
Stevef: is the "some don't" bucket larger than {Dreamweaver}?
Dreamweaver has had enough a11y people yelling at them
also, the "some don't" bucket doesn't disprove the existence of the "some do" bucket
i was stalking about editors that add name=generator by default dreamweaver doesn't appear to do that for me
the spec tries to empty the "some do" bucket
Stevef: Dreamweaver is a pro tool. It generally doesn't add stuff you don't ask for.
hsivonen: I guess we have to agree to disagree I made my points here: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/ChangeProposal/meta_name%3Dgenerator_does_not_make_missing_alt_conforming
hsivonen: its not the end of the world...
hsivonen:as i said the maciej earlier i was looking for a way out of the impasse that leads to FO
hsivonen: but its out of my hands now as it has been taken up formally by judy and the force...
Stevef: FWIW, I think "WYSIWYG" is immaterial. E.g. mass upload of photos to service that displays them in HTML wrappers faces the issue of not having alt text available without being WYSIWYG
Stevef: what's "the force"?
a11y taskforce
ah
i was being mischevious

hsivonen: for the mass upload use case i would suggest using figure/figcaption as it provides way to caption an image with an unambigous semantic that says this a caption, even if that caption is a filename
It's unclear to me, why it is useful to have an unambiguous semantic for caption if the camption is nonsensical
s/camption/caption/

hsivonen: it depends on if you think the filename is nonsensical. note in the vast majority of cases photo uploads are presented inside a link, so AT heaurstucs kick in and the filename is or worse is announced, difference with using figcaption is that at least the user can know its not a text alternative

Stevef: I mean that a caption like IMG_1234.jpg is only good for getting an identifier for the image. And if you want to grab an identifier, you might as well invoke the context menu and copy the URL of the image.

(.ogg and .webm FTW for streaming)

jgraham, not really, unless you care about recs
Well I think you know that *I* don't

if I do perl -pi -e 's/foo/bar/', what should I use to use an Unicode apostrophe as foo and an ASCII apostrophe as bar?
i.e. what escapes?
when the files are in UTF-8
Stevef: Wait … how does indicate "IMG_1234.jpg" is _not_ a text alternative in a way that does not, given that
hsivonen: \x{1234} will give you U+1234, and it sounds like doing "... -e 'use open (:std :utf8); s/foo/bar/'" will make it treat STDIN/STDOUT as UTF-8

webben: in firefox for example figcaption is mapped to IA2 caption role, also figcaption does not map to img accname itt maps to figure (role=group) accname (again in firefox as its the only browser that has implemented figure/figcaption semantics)
hadn't seen the 'open' pragma before, and usually does "binmode STDIN, ':utf8'" etc instead
suggests python
hsivonen: ...or "perl -CSD -pi -e 's/foo/bar/'"
(TIMTOWTDI)
Does perl mainly accept famous mathematical constats as command line arguments?

-pi isn't actually an argument, it's two single-character arguments that can be conveniently smushed together, except it can't be smushed with the -e since the -i consumes the remainder of its token as the extension to use when saving a backup of the files it's modifying, so you can't write "-pie"
if I remember correctly
(A lot like sed, because that's one of the many things Perl copied from)

I wonder if the creator of this image meant the connotations of the meme: http://a11ymemes.tumblr.com/post/23033757039/a-crying-woman-with-her-hand-over-her-face-says
It's interesting how a11y memes often don't use the idiomatic meme names
Is that First World Problems?
e.g. http://a11ymemes.tumblr.com/post/23037268835/philosophical-dinosour-says-if-html5-has doesn't say philociraptor
Ms2ger`: yes
and http://a11ymemes.tumblr.com/post/23104907769/action-man-so-i-built-this-bad-ass-website-and says "Action man" instead of "The Rock driving"
also Scumbag Steve is often called "lazy douchebag" on a11ymemes
and there's one without a proper text alternative: http://a11ymemes.tumblr.com/post/23091091673/bitch-pleeease
The nice thing about the text alternative on the a11y memes is that it makes them easier to follow for people not so well versed in the reddit culture (i.e. me)
Just as well they're not hidden away in some hard-to-access invisible attribute, really
(although it doesn't help much if the text alternative is missing the same context that I am missing)
thought part of the appeal of memes was their obscurity to outsiders
so highly visible text alternatives defeat the point
Appeal to whom?
To the people who use them and want to feel clever and superior
hsivoenen: It's interesting how a11y memes often don't use the idiomatic meme names - they are used when known, like i didn't know that philosoiraptor was called that
Kind of a weird way to feel clever and superior. "I put some text on a picture of a cat"
When memes appear on daytime TV programmes, they're no longer cool
Philip`: I thought they were about humor and not about superior feelings
hsivonen: feel free to comment on memes you think do not have correct text alternatives
It seems like the more-traditional method of quoting the entirity of uylesses from heart would be a better way to make yourself feel smug
*ulysses
Dammit, I am so inferior I can't even spell the title
Stevef: I'm not saying they aren't correct. I just think it's interesting how they tend to be more descriptive than idiomatic.
hsivonen:note many of the memes are created by someone for whom english is a second language
Stevef: I see, yes.
webben: we have a way to go before whats implemented actually works as it should

Maybe I'm confusing different types of memes - there are some that are popular because they're inherently entertaining, and others that are popular in niche communities despite having no inherent value since the context within that community makes them entertaining, and so people will find them entertaining and propagate them in order to be part of that community
Stevef: @src without alt is sufficient to determine there is no text alternative. It seems like moving the filename to the <figcaption> is just shifting the inaccessibility around.
A badly labelled group is not much better than a badly labelled image.
especially when UAs may use the group label to caption the image.
Stevef: I suppose figcaption allows image hosts to strip some of the gubbins out of the @src, but I'm not sure they can do that much more intelligently than client software.

(e.g. that Rick Astley video doesn't seem particularly entertaining by itself - its only value is to show you're part of a community that understands the wider context of tricking people into watching it)
(and it loses that value once pretty much everyone in the world understands it)
Stevef: cf. http://www.nvda-project.org/ticket/51 and http://www.nvda-project.org/ticket/1989
I think I would like to spread the meme that the co-opting of the word "meme" to mean "internet in-joke" is uncool
(whereas photos of cats are always enjoyable)

webben: true except that one at least rpovides and indication that it is something other than a text alternative and provides a method to identify an image, where as now if images don't have an alt they generally are ignored (unless inside a link) the figure/figcaption provides a method to say hey there is an image here, it has a caption of some sort but no text alternative
btw, will 3rd-party AT be locked out of Metro?
Stevef: But it's not a meaningful caption : it's basically the same repair text.
Stevef: @src is not a text alternative therefore that _is_ an indication that @src is not a text alternative.
Stevef: How client software surfaces the fact that it is repairing the absence of a text alternative is a different matter.

Stevef: I agree there's a problem with distinguishing significant and insignificant images without text alternatives, although I also think one could apply more intelligent heuristics than tend to be applied.
e.g. images below a certain rendered size are not significant (ad/tracking pixels)

webben: looking at flickr they provide a caption for all images http://www.flickr.com/photos/ which is usually better than the src value and in other cases there is no disernible source http://www.flickr.com/photos/pitschspics/7221150834/ so the figure/caption technique would be useful

webben or in these cases: http://www.flickr.com/photos/pitschspics/with/7221143506/ the caption while not that useful is a whole lot more useful than the src e.g. 7221058684_abb86bb0d8_m.jpg also note the alt and the caption are the same
Stevef: I agree that where the original filename is changed to some gibberish in a CDN URL as there, preserving the original filename in some sort of association with the is better than nothing.
webben: what I am trying to say is in practice when looking at how uploaded images on photo istes are captioned, using the figure/figcaption makes sense (to me)

webben: plus i like the figure/figcaption becuase it provides users with an easier way to provide some meaningful text thats programmatically associated with an image, it may not be the best text alternative, but its something and it can be conveyed that is NOT an alt text whereas if you use alt or title the AT does not know the difference (unless it goes in a qureries the DOM directly) as...
...they both populate the accname.
didn't know AT treats alt and title the same
that's pretty bad :(
annevk: its not AT as such its how the accessible name calculation works in all browsers (that support it)
annevk:mac works a little differently for images

annevk: essentially if there is no other source for an accessble name then browsers use the title, if alt is present as well as an a title alt is used for the name and title is used for the description

yeah, we should have the ele.on() concept instead
there are still problems with that approach

our designers don't want to go near html5 input validation, because they are adverse to bubble tooltips. I know you can style them, but is there a roadmap for that, in terms or extending the api to allow custom DOM insertion?
you can use setCustomValidity()
jreading: might be to start a thread on that though or a wiki page on Forms listing the shortcomings of what we have today
jreading: though for the 8 or so years we've been doing this nobody has wanted to take a hard look at styling forms :(
it's a rather hard problem
a shortcoming of the validation message bubbles as implemented is that if you have more than one invalid fiield only the first bubble shows
annevk: i'm not so concerned with the native styling, but just being able to change the placement and affect behavior
Stevef: sounds like a UI bug, yeah
jreading: that does sound like changing the native styling...
annevk: from what i can remember when testing its same behaviour across browsers
i suppose so, but I'm not asking for anyone to do that legwork, just need hooks for all that stuff
Stevef: just like type=file evolves over time so can this; UI is not standardized
jreading: I know, defining the hooks is the problem I'm referring to
right, ok
yannevk: understand but it limits its practical use currently
just like one can do <form novalidate> it would great to do <form message="inline | bubble | group">
